pullRequest.body:
Define KappaLindel√∂f spaces by following the first one-third of the API for Lindel√∂f spaces. The remainder will be added in a future PR. 

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
> This looks good, thanks! I want to have a second closer look, but here are small suggestions already.

Great, thanks! If you're reviewing: as you might notice, some results depend on `hreg : Cardinal.IsRegular Œ∫`, which comes up in `IsKLindelof.elim_cardinal_subcover`. It is crucially needed to apply `card_biUnion_lt_iff_forall_of_isRegular`, which is a result I recently added to `Cofinality`. I think that that result cannot do without the `Cardinal.IsRegular Œ∫` assumption, but I'm not entirely sure. If you think that that result can do without that assumption, I think I can get rid of all occurences of `hreg : Cardinal.IsRegular Œ∫`. Of course this has no effect on Lindel√∂f spaces, as they require aleph1, which is regular.

> > This looks good, thanks! I want to have a second closer look, but here are small suggestions already.
> 
> Great, thanks! If you're reviewing: as you might notice, some results depend on `hreg : Cardinal.IsRegular Œ∫`, which comes up in `IsKLindelof.elim_cardinal_subcover`. It is crucially needed to apply `card_biUnion_lt_iff_forall_of_isRegular`, which is a result I recently added to `Cofinality`. I think that that result cannot do without the `Cardinal.IsRegular Œ∫` assumption, but I'm not entirely sure. If you think that that result can do without that assumption, I think I can get rid of all occurences of `hreg : Cardinal.IsRegular Œ∫`. Of course this has no effect on Lindel√∂f spaces, as they require aleph1, which is regular.

I'm no expert in cardinal arithmetic, but I think that makes sense. This is a dumb counterexample, but for example this result (as well as the results on K-Lindelof I think ?) are clearly not true for finite cardinals.

> > > This looks good, thanks! I want to have a second closer look, but here are small suggestions already.
> > 
> > 
> > Great, thanks! If you're reviewing: as you might notice, some results depend on `hreg : Cardinal.IsRegular Œ∫`, which comes up in `IsKLindelof.elim_cardinal_subcover`. It is crucially needed to apply `card_biUnion_lt_iff_forall_of_isRegular`, which is a result I recently added to `Cofinality`. I think that that result cannot do without the `Cardinal.IsRegular Œ∫` assumption, but I'm not entirely sure. If you think that that result can do without that assumption, I think I can get rid of all occurences of `hreg : Cardinal.IsRegular Œ∫`. Of course this has no effect on Lindel√∂f spaces, as they require aleph1, which is regular.
> 
> I'm no expert in cardinal arithmetic, but I think that makes sense. This is a dumb counterexample, but for example this result (as well as the results on K-Lindelof I think ?) are clearly not true for finite cardinals.

Yes, you're right. Of course I would have to assume that the cardinal is infinite. I'll ask in the Zulip if an expert on this has some thoughts!
title should start with `feat: `, not `Feat : `.

The name K-Lindel√∂f is strange. Typically in topology, the letter K is used to denote compact, or compact covers. So I'd expect K-Lindel√∂f to be the property that for every k-cover (collection of open sets for which every compact (not just point) is contained in a set from the collection) has a countable k-cover.

However, $\kappa$-Lindel√∂f and Lindel√∂f degree are both appropriate, see e.g. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lindel%C3%B6f_space#Generalisation .
Ah, I see you've clocked https://topology.pi-base.org/properties/P000128 in your PR. I would still encourage e.g. replacing each `KLindelof` with `KappaLindelof` to avoid confusion with k-Lindel√∂f.
I haven't thought too carefully about it yet, but I'd suspect that several of the results here hold for any infinite cardinal, not just regular cardinals.

> The name K-Lindel√∂f is strange. Typically in topology, the letter K is used to denote compact, or compact covers. So I'd expect K-Lindel√∂f to be the property that for every k-cover (collection of open sets for which every compact (not just point) is contained in a set from the collection) has a countable k-cover.
> 
> However, Œ∫-Lindel√∂f and Lindel√∂f degree are both appropriate, see e.g. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lindel%C3%B6f_space#Generalisation .

Yes, you are right, I was afraid that writing \kappa would be confusing, but I could have of course written it out as KappaLindel√∂f. I like this idea a lot, I will adjust this in my next commit.

> I haven't thought too carefully about it yet, but I'd suspect that several of the results here hold for any infinite cardinal, not just regular cardinals.



> I haven't thought too carefully about it yet, but I'd suspect that several of the results here hold for any infinite cardinal, not just regular cardinals.

Let me start by saying that topology is not my expertise nor research area (I'm into Financial Mathematics), so I'm certain that you will have a better understanding of what can/cannot be proven about these spaces, @StevenClontz. Let me explain why I need regularity here, I'm curious to hear your thoughts on the matter.

First of all, `IsCompact` and `IsLindel√∂f` are defined in terms of filters rather than open covers. By analogy, I wanted to do the same thing for `IsKappaLindel√∂f`. This goes well, until `IsKappaLindelof.elim_cardinal_subcover`, which is the result that proves that the filter-based definition of `IsKappaLindel√∂f` reduces to the "usual" definition of these spaces. Here we need to show that a union of less than `Œ∫` sets which are each of cardinality less than `Œ∫` again has cardinality less than `Œ∫`. This is https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/SetTheory/Cardinal/Cofinality.html#Cardinal.card_biUnion_lt_iff_forall_of_isRegular, which I added a while back (for this purpose) and for which I couldn't manage to prove the needed direction without assuming `Œ∫` was regular. Any result that is currently proven using this open cover property then automatically needs this assumption that `Œ∫` is regular, which is a bit unfortunate. 

I could try to redefine everything in terms of open covers, but I wasn't entirely sure if we wouldn't end up needing regularity later on anyway. If you have thoughts on this, I'm very happy to hear them.

On the other hand, if you know of a way to make https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/SetTheory/Cardinal/Cofinality.html#Cardinal.card_biUnion_lt_iff_forall_of_isRegular independent of the regularity assumption (and replacing it by assuming that the cardinal is infinite), I'm more than happy to hear this as well, but I'm not sure if this is possible mathematically. (The way I understand regularity is that it sort of imposes this very property).

The property that a union of $<\kappa$ sets of cardinality $<\kappa$ will have cardinality $<\kappa$ is definitely restricted to regular cardinals: consider $\bigcup\\{\omega_n:n<\omega\\}=\omega_\omega$.

I will need to brush up on the filter characterization of these covering properties to see if there's another approach. I also have asked at https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/4907143/singular-cardinals-and-kappa-lindel%c3%b6f-spaces to see if singular-cardinality $\kappa$-Lindelof is even a useful concept: for example every discrete space is $\kappa^+$-Lindelof, and successor cardinals are always regular. EDIT: Izaak van Dongen has shown how to construct $\aleph_\alpha$-Lindel√∂f spaces for any limit ordinal $\alpha$ that are not $\kappa$-Lindel√∂f for any $\kappa<\aleph_\alpha$. So (at least at some point) one might be interested in the case where $\kappa$ is singular.

> The property that a union of <Œ∫ sets of cardinality <Œ∫ will have cardinality <Œ∫ is definitely restricted to regular cardinals: consider ‚ãÉ{œân:n<œâ}=œâœâ.
> 
> I will need to brush up on the filter characterization of these covering properties to see if there's another approach. I also have asked at https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/4907143/singular-cardinals-and-kappa-lindel%c3%b6f-spaces to see if singular-cardinality Œ∫-Lindelof is even a useful concept: for example every discrete space is Œ∫+-Lindelof, and successor cardinals are always regular. EDIT: Izaak van Dongen has shown how to construct ‚ÑµŒ±-Lindel√∂f spaces for any limit ordinal Œ± that are not Œ∫-Lindel√∂f for any Œ∫<‚ÑµŒ±. So (at least at some point) one might be interested in the case where Œ∫ is singular.

Thank you for following up on this. When you know whether the filter characterisation can be fruitfully used here, please let me know. If not, I guess we should pass to the open cover characterisation instead!
I expect this question will be easy for the right person, so I've asked it here: https://mathoverflow.net/questions/470222/filter-vs-cover-characterization-of-covering-properties

> I expect this question will be easy for the right person, so I've asked it here: https://mathoverflow.net/questions/470222/filter-vs-cover-characterization-of-covering-properties

Ha, the discrete space of size singular $\kappa$ is the counterexample: it's not $\kappa$-Lindel√∂f in the cover sense, but it is $\kappa$-Lindel√∂f in the filter sense.

> > I expect this question will be easy for the right person, so I've asked it here: https://mathoverflow.net/questions/470222/filter-vs-cover-characterization-of-covering-properties
> 
> Ha, the discrete space of size singular Œ∫ is the counterexample: it's not Œ∫-Lindel√∂f in the cover sense, but it is Œ∫-Lindel√∂f in the filter sense.

So do you think we should then use the cover definition instead?

I'm still new to mathlib, so I can't say with confidence. But as an active researcher in topology, I'd be quite perplexed to see $\kappa$-Lindel√∂f not being equivalent to the covering definition.

Maybe this is `KappaFilterLindelof` and there's also `KappaCoverLindelof` and there's a theorem showing their equivalence when $\kappa$ is regular?

Of course, it's still unclear to me who in the community can have the final say whether a PR gets merged, but whoever they are, their opinion would be most important here. üôÉ
Let's ask @ADedecker and @urkud about their thoughts on this then!
I'm not an expert in topology, so I don't know which definition is better.
I am a bit worried that this is a super technical definition without any clear motivation. @JADekker could you tell us what you intend to do with this definition?

> I am a bit worried that this is a super technical definition without any clear motivation. @JADekker could you tell us what you intend to do with this definition?

So my goal in this PR was to generalize the results that we have for Lindel√∂f spaces to so-called Kappa-Lindel√∂f spaces (see Generalisation here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lindel%C3%B6f_space?wprov=sfti1#Example:_the_Sorgenfrey_plane_is_not_Lindel%C3%B6f), which I did by eyeballing the right generalization based on the insights that I had in going from Compact to Lindel√∂f.
And I prove at some point that this filter-based definition is in fact the right definition (modulo an additional regularity condition).
I understand this is a generalization, my question is: what do you plan to do with it?

Formalizing these spaces was the final goal. I figured people might be interested in them at some point, and I figured it would be efficient if I wrote up some API with the insights I gained from formalizing Lindel√∂f spaces.

We will finish the process here since you already worked a lot, but please keep in mind that we don‚Äôt want to add uncountably many classes of topological spaces only because they appear in pi-base. This was discussed extensively on Zulip in the ‚ÄúTracking pi-base‚Äù thread.

> We will finish the process here since you already worked a lot, but please keep in mind that we don‚Äôt want to add uncountably many classes of topological spaces only because they appear in pi-base. This was discussed extensively on Zulip in the ‚ÄúTracking pi-base‚Äù thread.

Yes, you‚Äôre right. I‚Äôm aware of that thread. I think I started this effort before we reached that conclusion in the thread, but I‚Äôm happy to close the PR and leave it around until someone needs it for something else! I‚Äôm a bit busy with my own research now anyway, so I won‚Äôt have a lot of time for lean in the coming weeks anyway‚Ä¶

My two cents: this concept is something that I would not be surprised to see in a research paper, but a bit more surprised to see in a graduate topology course.

FWIW the vague plan is to find a way for users to contribute Lean formalizations to https://github.com/pi-base/data (whether it's simply a pointer to the existing formalization in Mathlib, or new code that uses Mathlib as a dependency). No time-table for that exists however.

A final note. There are in fact editorial standards for what gets put into pi-Base: we are a database of results that are of interest to researchers, so everything needs to be connected to standard textbook results, or else a peer-reviewed paper. So there's no fear of uncountably-many results being introduced in pi-Base, but I do think we're interested in modeling a bigger chunk of topology than Mathlib is. (Actually, I don't think this property is in pi-Base currently, but it's certainly in scope. It'd need to be $\aleph_1$-Lindelof since we don't support properties defined for arbitrary cardinalities, yet.)

> A final note. There are in fact editorial standards for what gets put into pi-Base: we are a database of results that are of interest to researchers, so everything needs to be connected to standard textbook results, or else a peer-reviewed paper. So there's no fear of uncountably-many results being introduced in pi-Base, but I do think we're interested in modeling a bigger chunk of topology than Mathlib is. (Actually, I don't think this property is in pi-Base currently, but it's certainly in scope. It'd need to be ‚Ñµ1-Lindelof since we don't support properties defined for arbitrary cardinalities, yet.)

I never meant to suggest there are no editorial standards in pi-base! I simply meant that Mathlib and pi-base have different goals so they have different standards, so being suitable for pi-base does not automatically imply being suitable for Mathlib.

It seems you have a merge conflict. Can you fix this, please?

Let me also label this awaiting-zulip, as a notice that this PR might merit a discussion/ensuring it does not get forgotten.

> It seems you have a merge conflict. Can you fix this, please?
> 
> Let me also label this awaiting-zulip, as a notice that this PR might merit a discussion/ensuring it does not get forgotten.

@grunweg Yes, will do! I've been swamped by my own research project for the last months, and with teaching coming up, I don't know when exactly I'll have time to return to some more serious Lean, so I'll pick it up once I find some time for this. I think this file is rather much of a leaf-file to Mathlib, but if it blocks progress/someone wants to see it in Mathlib soon, anyone is free to push to this branch based on the corresponding Zulip chat!

I haven‚Äôt had time for Lean in the past weeks/months, and I don‚Äôt foresee time in the next two months due to teaching & research obligations. Happy to let someone else adopt this one, otherwise I‚Äôll return to it once I have time! Same applies to https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/12087, which is a follow-up (which still needs some naming updates.
This looks good, thanks! I want to have a second closer look, but here are small suggestions already.

```suggestion
* This API is mainly based on the API for `IsCompact` and `IsLindelof` and follows notation and style as
```

```suggestion
/-- To show that a `k`-Lindel√∂f set intersects the intersection of a family of closed sets,
```

```suggestion
* `NonKLindelofSpace`: a space that is not a k-Lindel√∂f space, e.g. the Long Line.
```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion * This API is mainly based on the API for `IsCompact` and `IsLindelof` and follows notation ```

```suggestion

TODO: Add the following (in a future PR)
```

Otherwise it looks to me like the TODO refers to the previous list item
I think this needs to be updated.

```suggestion
variable {k : Cardinal.{u}}
```

Lean doesn't need it, but it's more readable imo.
Could you explicitly mention this is not the same as https://topology.pi-base.org/properties/P000128 ? Maybe by using kappa instead of k (just an idea, if you don't like it feel free to ignore).

```suggestion
a `k`-Lindel√∂f set `s` contains any open set that contains all clusterpoints of `f` in `s`. -/
```

Could you do the same fix in the file about Lindelof spaces?

pullRequest.title: feat : Define KappaLindel√∂f spaces

source.title: feat : complete API for K-Lindel√∂f spaces

> I am a bit worried that this is a super technical definition without any clear motivation. @JADekker could you tell us what you intend to do with this definition?

So my goal in this PR was to generalize the results that we have for Lindel√∂f spaces to so-called Kappa-Lindel√∂f spaces (see Generalisation here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lindel%C3%B6f_space?wprov=sfti1#Example:_the_Sorgenfrey_plane_is_not_Lindel%C3%B6f), which I did by eyeballing the right generalization based on the insights that I had in going from Compact to Lindel√∂f.
And I prove at some point that this filter-based definition is in fact the right definition (modulo an additional regularity condition).
I understand this is a generalization, my question is: what do you plan to do with it?

Formalizing these spaces was the final goal. I figured people might be interested in them at some point, and I figured it would be efficient if I wrote up some API with the insights I gained from formalizing Lindel√∂f spaces.

We will finish the process here since you already worked a lot, but please keep in mind that we don‚Äôt want to add uncountably many classes of topological spaces only because they appear in pi-base. This was discussed extensively on Zulip in the ‚ÄúTracking pi-base‚Äù thread.

> We will finish the process here since you already worked a lot, but please keep in mind that we don‚Äôt want to add uncountably many classes of topological spaces only because they appear in pi-base. This was discussed extensively on Zulip in the ‚ÄúTracking pi-base‚Äù thread.

Yes, you‚Äôre right. I‚Äôm aware of that thread. I think I started this effort before we reached that conclusion in the thread, but I‚Äôm happy to close the PR and leave it around until someone needs it for something else! I‚Äôm a bit busy with my own research now anyway, so I won‚Äôt have a lot of time for lean in the coming weeks anyway‚Ä¶

My two cents: this concept is something that I would not be surprised to see in a research paper, but a bit more surprised to see in a graduate topology course.

FWIW the vague plan is to find a way for users to contribute Lean formalizations to https://github.com/pi-base/data (whether it's simply a pointer to the existing formalization in Mathlib, or new code that uses Mathlib as a dependency). No time-table for that exists however.

A final note. There are in fact editorial standards for what gets put into pi-Base: we are a database of results that are of interest to researchers, so everything needs to be connected to standard textbook results, or else a peer-reviewed paper. So there's no fear of uncountably-many results being introduced in pi-Base, but I do think we're interested in modeling a bigger chunk of topology than Mathlib is. (Actually, I don't think this property is in pi-Base currently, but it's certainly in scope. It'd need to be $\aleph_1$-Lindelof since we don't support properties defined for arbitrary cardinalities, yet.)

It'd need to be ‚Ñµ1-Lindelof since we don't support properties defined for arbitrary cardinalities, yet.)

I never meant to suggest there are no editorial standards in pi-base! I simply meant that Mathlib and pi-base have different goals so they have different standards, so being suitable for pi-base does not automatically imply being suitable for Mathlib.
